member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Gui.Controls.ISelectable
member.summary: An object which can be selected, such as a text box which can be be selected to receive input, or a button which can be selected when tabbing through a list of buttonsn to recieve the click event by pressing the Enter key.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor
member.summary: The cursor is a controllable graphical icon which can interact with FRB elements and stores information about mouse activity.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.mWindowSecondaryPushed
member.summary: The window that the cursor was over when the mouse button was pressed.
member.remarks: When the secondary (right) mouse button is pushed down, this value is set - either to null if the mouse is not over any Windows or to the Window that the mouse is over. When the secondary mouse button is released (clicked), this value is set to null. This value is useful for clicking on Windows. Specifically, when the cursor is clicked on a Button, the WindowPushed value is tested to make sure that it is the same as the Window clicked on. This allows for players to push on a Button but move the mouse away and click elsewhere without clicking on the Button originally pushed and without accidentally clicking on other Buttons. This is also used with ToggleButtons to control when they are pressed and unpressed.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.StaticPosition
member.summary: If this value is true, the Cursor will not move in response to the mouse or gamepad.
member.remarks: This value can be set to true if the Cursor should not move in response to input. The staticPosition value is only used by the engine when over the button on an UpDown. When pushing down on an UpDown button, the staticPosition is set to true, and set to false when releasing the mouse button.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.WindowGrabbed
member.summary: The window that the cursor has grabbed.
member.remarks: When the mouse button is released, the windowGrabbed reference is set to null. If a Window is grabbed, it will move as the mouse moves. This is used commonly for dragging on menu bars and scroll bars. The cursor does not recognize which types of Windows can be dragged, so windows must be grabbed through the Cursor.GrabWindow method. The windowGrabbed's onDrag event is fired every frame.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.mObjectGrabbed
member.summary: Storage for reference to a grabbed object.
member.remarks: This variable has no internal engine functionality. It merely provies a place to store a reference to a grabbed Object - useful in graphical applications where the Cursor can grab and move objects such as Sprites or Text objects. The ObjectGrabbedRelativeX and ObjectGrabbedRelativeY can also be set to keep the object static after a click rather than "snapping" its center to the Cursor's tip.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.ObjectGrabbedRelativeX
member.summary: The relative x position of a grabbed object from the center of the cursor.
member.remarks: This value can be set through the SetObjectRelativePosition. This value used in the GetCursorPositionForSprite method.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.ObjectGrabbedRelativeY
member.summary: The relative y position of a grabbed object from the center of the cursor.
member.remarks: This value can be set through the SetObjectRelativePosition. This value used in the GetCursorPositionForSprite method.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.PrimaryPush
member.summary: Whether the primary button was pushed this frame. A push is when the primary button is not down last frame but is down this frame.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.PrimaryDown
member.summary: Determines whether the primary button is down this frame.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.PrimaryClick
member.summary: Whether the primary button was clicked (released) this frame. A release is when the primary button is down last frame but not down this frame.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.PrimaryDoubleClick
member.summary: Determines whether the primary button was double clicked this frame.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.SecondaryPush
member.summary: Determines whether the secondary button was pushed this frame.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.SecondaryDown
member.summary: Determines whether the secondary button is down this frame.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.SecondaryClick
member.summary: Determines whether the secondary button was clicked (released) this frame.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.SecondaryDoubleClick
member.summary: Determines whether the secondary button was double clicked this frame.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.DevicesControllingCursor
member.summary: The IInputDevices controlling the cursor. By default this is the Mouse.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.mCamera
member.summary: Reference to the camera to which the cursor belongs.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.WindowOver
member.summary: Returns the Window that this cursor is over. If the cursor is not over any Window, this value will be null.
member.remarks: This value is usually used in two situations: 1. To test if the cursor is over a Window to prevent clicking on objects in the game world. For example, this is checked first, then tests against entities are performed if this value is null. 2. To diagnose UI issues. The WindowOver can be printed to the screen to detect if which window is receiving cursor input.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.PrimaryButton
member.summary: The Primary button (usually left mouse button) which can be tested for clicks, pushes, and if it is held down.
member.remarks: This object is internally created only once, and that same reference is returned on subsequent calls to keep allocation low.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.LastInputDevice
member.summary: The lsat InputDevice that controlled the cursor. Typically this would be a touch screen or mouse.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.Active
member.summary: Sets whether the cursor is active.
member.remarks:
An inactive cursor will not move or read any input. Setting the active property to false will also clear the following fields:
primaryClick
primaryDoubleClick
primaryDown
primaryPush
secondaryClick
secondaryDoubleClick
secondaryDown
secondaryPush

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.RequiresGameWindowInFocus
member.summary: Whether the game window must be in focus to perform cursor logic. If false, then clicks will be processed even if the Window isn't in focus.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.ZVelocity
member.summary: The movement rate of the controlling input (usually mouse) on the z axis. For the mouse this refers to the scroll wheel.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.ScreenX
member.summary: The number of pixels between the left of the screen and the cursor. Note that this does not consider the camera's position, orientation, or perspective - it will always return 0 at the left-edge of the screen.
member.remarks: This can be set if the cursor is using an input device which modifies the position incrementally (such as an XboxGamePad). If using an input device which sets the position in absolute coordiantes (such as a Mouse), this value will be overwritten every frame.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.ScreenY
member.summary: The number of pixels between the top of the screen and the cursor. Note that this does not consider the camera's position, orientation, or perspective - it will always return 0 at the top-edge of the screen. This value increases downward.
member.remarks: This can be set if the cursor is using an input device which modifies the position incrementally (such as an XboxGamePad). If using an input device which sets the position in absolute coordiantes (such as a Mouse), this value will be overwritten every frame.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.ScreenXChange
member.summary: Returns the number of pixels on the X axis that the cursor has moved since the last frame. This can be used to move grabbed windows.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.ScreenYChange
member.summary: Returns the number of pixels on the Y axis that the cursor has moved since the last frame. This can be used to move grabbed windows.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.WindowPushed
member.summary: The window that the cursor was over when the mouse button was pressed.
member.remarks: When the mouse button is pushed down, this value is set - either to null if the mouse is not over any Windows or to the Window that the mouse is over. When the mouse button is released (clicked), this value is set to null. This value is useful for clicking on Windows. Specifically, when the cursor is clicked on a Button, the WindowPushed value is tested to make sure that it is the same as the Window clicked on. This allows for players to push on a Button but move the mouse away and click elsewhere without clicking on the Button originally pushed and without accidentally clicking on other Buttons. This is also used with ToggleButtons to control when they are pressed and unpressed.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.ObjectGrabbed
member.summary: Assigns the ObjectGrabbed and calculates the relative position of the grabbed object. After this method is called, UpdateObjectGrabbedPosition can be called every frame to position the grabbed object.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.CustomUpdate
member.summary: Delegate which can be used to apply custom positioning and button state logic. The argument is the Cursor instance, and the bool indicates whether the internal Cursor logic should apply click and push values.
member.remarks: If the CustomUpdate delegate assigns Click, Push, and DoubleClick values internally, then it should return false, indicating that the Cursor logic itself shouldn't. If the CustomUpdate only modifies the down states, then the CustomUpdate delegate should return true so that the Click, Push, and DoubleClick values are

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.#ctor(FlatRedBall.Camera)
member.summary: Creates a new Cursor
member.remarks: Usually the cursor does not have to be created explicitly. Calling the GuiManager's constructor without a cursor reference (default in the FrbTemplate) creates a cursor automatically. New cursors should only be created if multiple cursors are needed, or if you are inheriting from the Cursor class. Usually multiple cursors are only needed in games with multiple cameras.
member.param: The camera that the cursor will belong to.

member.remarks: As the cursor can control objects at various Z values, this method returns the X velocity of the cursor at a paritular Z. This method assumes that the Camera is unrotated (looking down the Z axis.

member.returns: The X velocity at the particular Z.

The Layer to use for velocity calculations

member.returns: The Y velocity at the particular Z.

The Z value at which the position should be set.

member.summary: Grabs a Window with the Cursor.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.IsOn(FlatRedBall.Sprite)
member.summary: Determines whether the cursor is on a Sprite, but only considers rotation on the z axis (RotationZ).
member.remarks:
This method will not consider whether spriteToTest is rotated on the x or y axes, and assumes that the camera is looking down the Z axis (the Camera is unrotated). Cursor.IsOn3D works properly for any rotation..
This method will not select Sprites which are closer that the camera's nearClipPlane or further than the camera's farClipPlane.
member.param: The Sprite to test if the cursor is over.
member.returns: Whether the cursor is on the Sprite.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.IsOn(FlatRedBall.Graphics.Text)
member.summary: Determines whether the cursor is over a textObject.
member.param: The TextObject to test if the cursor is over.
member.returns: Whether the cursor is on the TextObject.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.IsOn``1(``0)
member.summary: Returns whether the cursor is over the argument SpriteFrame.
member.param: Reference to the SpriteFrame to test.
member.returns: Whether the cursor is over the argument SpriteFrame.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.IsOn3D(FlatRedBall.Sprite)
member.summary: Determines whether the Cursor is on a Sprite.
member.remarks:
This is the "full featured" version of the IsOn method, considering rotation on all axes for both the spriteToTest and the camera. All lookingStyles are considered and will return accurate results. This method is slower than the IsOn method, and if Sprites are facing the camera under its default orientation, the IsOn method should be used.
This method will not select Sprites if the cursor is over them on a point that is closer that the camera's nearClipPlane or further than the camera's farClipPlane.
member.param: The Sprite to test if the Cursor is over.
member.returns: Whether the Cursor is over the Sprite.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.Cursor.IsOn3D(FlatRedBall.Sprite,Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector3@)
member.summary: Determines whether the Cursor is on a Sprite and stores the intersection point in a Vector3.
member.remarks:
This is the "full featured" version of the IsOn method, considering rotation on all axes for both the spriteToTest and the camera. All lookingStyles are considered and will return accurate results. This method is slower than the IsOn method, and if Sprites are facing the camera under its default orientation, the IsOn method should be used.
This method also modifies a Vector3 which marks the intersection point on the Sprite.
This method will not select Sprites if the cursor is over them on a point that is closer that the camera's nearClipPlane or further than the camera's farClipPlane.
member.param: The Sprite to test if the Cursor is over.
The point where the cursor touches the Sprite.
member.returns: Whether the Cursor is on the Sprite.

member.returns: Whether the cursor is currently in the active Control which owns the application.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.GuiManager.mDominantWindows
member.summary: A stack of Windows which demand input from the cursor.
member.remarks: When a dominantWindow is valid, the cursor will not be able to interact with other windows. If RemoveInvisibleDominantWindows is set to true (default is true) then the GuiManager will remove any invisible dominant windows from its memory. In other words a DominantWindow can be removed either through the traditional Remove methods or by setting the Window's Visible property to false if RemoveInvisibleDominantWindows is true.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Gui.GuiManager.mToolTipText
member.summary: Sets the tool tip to show
member.remarks: Some UI elements like Buttons automatically show a tool tip. This property can be used to overwrite what is shown, or to show tool tips when the user is over a non-UI element.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.GuiManager.Cursor
member.summary: Gets the main cursor. If multiple cursors have been added to the GuiManager, returns the first one.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.GuiManager.GamePadsForUiControl
member.summary: The list of Xbox360GamePads used to control UI elements (tabbing and selecting)

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.GuiManager.AddDominantWindow(FlatRedBall.Gui.IWindow)
member.summary: Adds a window as a Dominant Window. If the window is a regular Window already managed by the GuiManager it will be removed from the regularly-managed window list. If the window is already a dominant window, this operation does nothing, so it can be called multiple times.
member.param: The window to add to the Dominant Window stack.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.GuiManager.SortZAndLayerBased
member.summary: Sorts all contained IWindows according to their Z values and Layers. This will usually result in clicks being received in the same order that objects are drawn, which is what the user will usually expect.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Gui.FocusUpdateDelegate
member.summary: Event raised by the Keyboard every frame on the InputManager's ReceivingInput reference.
member.param: The current IInputReceiver.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Gui.IInputReceiver
member.summary: Interface for objects which can receive input from the InputManager.
member.remarks:
This interface should only be used for Gui elements specifically because the GuiManager will change the InputManager.ReceivingInput reference depending on the activity of the cursor and other Gui elements. The InputManager will only keep track of one IInputReceiver at a time, and each IInputReceiver needs to assign itself as the target for input through the static InputManager.ReceivingInput field.
Since this is only used for Gui elements, this interface is rarely used in games.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.IInputReceiver.TakingInput
member.summary: A method which determines whether the instance can currently receive focus as an input receiver.
member.returns: Whether the instance is taking input.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Gui.IInputReceiver.NextInTabSequence
member.summary: The next IInputReceiver in the tab sequence. In other words, if this element is currently receiving input (is the InputManager's ReceivingInput), pressing tab will set the NextInTabSequence to be the InputManager's ReceivingInput.

member.name: E:FlatRedBall.Gui.IInputReceiver.FocusUpdate
member.summary: Event raised every frame if there is a non-null InputManager.ReceivingInput. This allows the IInputReceiver to perform custom every-frame logic when it has focus, such as a ListBox listening for the Delete key to delete highlighted elements.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.IInputReceiver.OnFocusUpdate
member.summary: Called by the InputManager automatically every frame.
member.remarks: The implementation of this method should raise the FocusUpdate event.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.IInputReceiver.OnGainFocus
member.summary: Called by the engine automatically when an IInputReceiver gains focus.
member.remarks: The implementation of this method should raise the GainFocus event.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.IInputReceiver.LoseFocus
member.summary: Called by the engine automatically when an IInputReceiver loses focus.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Gui.IInputReceiver.ReceiveInput
member.summary: The method called every frame by the InputManager in the Update method if this is the IInputReceiver referenced by the InputManager. This does not have to be called automatically.

member.name: E:FlatRedBall.Gui.IWindow.Click
member.summary: An event raised when the window is clicked (the user pushes and releases on the window)

member.name: E:FlatRedBall.Gui.IWindow.ClickNoSlide
member.summary: An event raised when the window is pushed and released without moving.

member.name: E:FlatRedBall.Gui.IWindow.SlideOnClick
member.summary: An event raised when the cursor is pushed when not on the window, but then released when it is on the window. This can be used as a drag+drop event.

member.name: E:FlatRedBall.Gui.IWindow.Push
member.summary: An event raised when the cursor is pushed (not down last frame, is on this frame)

member.name: E:FlatRedBall.Gui.IWindow.DragOver
member.summary: Event raied when the cursor moves and this window is the pressed window. This is called whether the cursor is over the current window or not.

member.name: E:FlatRedBall.Gui.IWindow.RollOn
member.summary: An event raised when the cursor moves onto the window for the first time. This is raised only once until the user moves the cursor off and then back on.

member.name: E:FlatRedBall.Gui.IWindow.RollOff
member.summary: An event raised when the cursor moves off of the window

member.name: E:FlatRedBall.Gui.IWindow.RollOver
member.summary: An event raised when the cursor moves while it is over the window. This is raised every frame that the cursor moves and is over the window. This event is not raised unless the cursor is over the window.

member.name: E:FlatRedBall.Gui.IWindow.EnabledChange
member.summary: Event raised when the Enabled property changes on the window.

member.name: E:FlatRedBall.Gui.IWindow.RemovedAsPushedWindow
member.summary: Event raised when this Window is pushed, then is no longer the pushed window due to a cursor releasing the primary button.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Gui.WindowArray
member.summary: Summary description for WindowArray.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogButton
member.summary: A button or single-axis input device which can return a range of values. Common examples include shoulder triggers on the Xbox360GamePad.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogButton.Position
member.summary: The current value of the AnalogButton, with ranges 0 - 1

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Input.DeadzoneInterpolationType.Instant
member.summary: No interpolation is performed. Values less than the deadzone are set to 0.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Input.DeadzoneInterpolationType.Linear
member.summary: Linear interpolation is performed for values greater than the deadzone.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Input.DeadzoneInterpolationType.Quadratic
member.summary: Quadratic (in) interpolation is performed for values greater than the deadzone. This increases accuracy at lower values (values closer to the deadzone) so that small movements are easier to perform.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogStick
member.summary: A two-axis input device which can return a range of values on both axes.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogStick.DPadOnValue
member.summary: The DPadOnValue and DPadOffValue values are used to simulate D-Pad control with the analog stick. When the user is above the absolute value of the mDPadOnValue then it is as if the DPad is held down. To release the DPad the value must come under the off value. If there was only one value then the user could hold the stick near the threshold and get rapid on/off values due to the inaccuracy of the analog stick. Therefore the DPadOnValue must be larger than DPadOffValue. The spread between these values should be large enough to prevent rapid on/off values, but small enough so the user can still release the analog stick and have it feel like a DPad.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogStick.DefaultTimeAfterPush
member.summary: Number of seconds to wait after a push before repeating.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogStick.DefaultTimeBetweenRepeating
member.summary: Number of seconds between repeating.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogStick.LeftAsButton
member.summary: Returns the left direction of the analog stick as an AnalogButton instance.
member.remarks: Value range is 0 to 1. Value if analog stick is held all the way to the left is 1. Note that the value is positive in this case, which is the opposite of the AnalogStick's Position.X. Value if analog stick is in neutral position is 0. Value if analog stick is held all the way to the right is still 0.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogStick.RightAsButton
member.summary: Returns the right direction of the analog stick as an AnalogButton instance.
member.remarks: Value range is 0 to 1. Value if analog stick is held all the way to the left is 0. Value if analog stick is in neutral position is 0. Value if analog stick is held all the way to the right is 1.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogStick.UpAsButton
member.summary: Returns the up direction of the analog stick as an AnalogButton instance.
member.remarks: Value range is 0 to 1. Value if analog stick is held all the way downward is 0. Value if analog stick is in neutral position is 0. Value if analog stick is held all the way upward is 1.

members.member:
Returns the down direction of the analog stick as an AnalogButton instance.
Value range is 0 to 1. Value if analog stick is held all the way downward is 1. Note that the value is positive, which is the opposite of the AnalogStick's Position.Y. Value if analog stick is in neutral position is 0. Value if analog stick is held all the way upward is 0.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogStick.Angle
member.summary: Returns the angle of the analog stick in radians. 0 is to the right, Pi/2 is up, Pi is to the left, and 3*Pi/2 is down. If the analog stick's position is (0,0), the Angle returned is 0 (to the right).

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogStick.Magnitude
member.summary: Gets the distance from the center position of the analog stick. Value is between 0 and 1, where 0 is the neutral position.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogStick.TimeAfterPush
member.summary: The time between a button is first pressed and the button starts repeating its input.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogStick.TimeBetweenRepeating
member.summary: The time between repeat presses once a button has been held down.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogStick.Position
member.summary: The position of the analog stick after applying deadzone. The range for each component is -1 to 1.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogStick.IsMaxPositionNormalized
member.summary: Whether Position values should be limited so that Position.Length is less than or equal to 1. This is recommended for top-down games.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogStick.RawPosition
member.summary: The position of the analog stick before deadzone, deadzone interpolation, and normalization are applied.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogStick.Velocity
member.summary: The change in units per second of the analog stick, where 1 unit is the distance from the center to the edge of the analog stick.
member.remarks: This measures the physical movement (rather than position) of the analog stick, which can be used to detect taps for dashing, or "smash attacks" like in Super Smash Bros.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogStick.DeadzoneInterpolation
member.summary: The type of interpolation to perform up to the max value when outside of the deadzone value.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogStick.AsDPadPushed(FlatRedBall.Input.Xbox360GamePad.DPadDirection)
member.summary: Returns whether the user has pressed a particular direction, returning true only once per push similar to a d-pad. This can be used for UI navigation.
member.param: The direction to test
member.returns: Whether the direction was pressed.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Input.AnalogStick.Update(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Vector2)
member.summary: Updates the internal values (position, DPad simulated values, velocity) according to the argument newPosition. Values will be adjusted according to the AnalogStick's deadzone values.
member.param: The normalized (-1 to +1) position of the analog stick.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Input.InputDeviceBase
member.summary:
Base class for creating customizable input. This class provides default implementations for all IInputDevice properties. Games can freely implement properties as needed by overriding the virtual Get methods.
By default a new InputDeviceBase instance can be used as a device which always returns 0 and false.
member.remarks:
The overridable methods will only be read one time per frame, and only if the InputDeviceBase is asked for any of its default values. In other words, if the Default2DInput value is checked multiple times in a frame, the GetDefault2DInputX and GetDefault2DInputY values will only be read one time per frame. This guarantees input consistency across a frame, similar to how input hardware (like a Keyboard) behaves.
The InputDeviceBase includes Get functions for bool input values like primary action, secondary action, confirm, and join. Only the current-frame value is controlled by the Get functions. Internally, the InputDeviceBase keeps track of the values returned last frame, and will properly report WasJustPressed and WasJustReleased appropriately.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Input.InputDeviceBase.GetPrimaryActionPressed
member.summary: Returns whether the primary action input is pressed this frame.
member.returns: Whether the primary action input is pressed this frame.

Justin 3/19/22: added optional arguments to explicitly ignore directional and analog inputs as buttons as these are often not intended to register as buttons. The defaults ensure back compat.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Input.Xbox360GamePad.Clear
member.summary: Clears the input on this controller for this frame. This includes analog stick values, button values, trigger values, and vibration motor values (resets to 0).

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Input.Xbox360GamePad.CreateDefaultButtonMap
member.summary: Creates a ButtonMap for this controller using the default bindings. This is a quick way to simulate an Xbox360 controller using the keyboard.
member.remarks:
This creates the following bindings: * Left analog stick = arrow keys * A button = A key * B button = S key * X button = Q key * Y button = W key * Left trigger = E key * Right trigger = R key * Left shoulder = D key * Right Shoulder = F key * Back button = Backspace key * Start button = Enter key
This will not simulate that the controller is connected, so you will have to set FakeIsConnected to true if your game checks the connected state.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Input.Xbox360GamePad.IgnoreButtonForOneFrame(FlatRedBall.Input.Xbox360GamePad.Button)
member.summary: Makes this Xbox360Gamepad ignore the argument button for the rest of the current frame.
member.param: The button that should be ignored for the rest of the current frame.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Input.Xbox360GamePad.Update(Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Input.GamePadState)
member.summary: Updates the Xbox360Gamepad according to the argument gamepadState. This is publicly available for games which need to simulate Xbox360Gamepads.
member.remarks: This function is normally called automatically by the FlatRedBall Engine in its regular update loop. You only need to call this function if you want to override the behavior of the gamepad. Be sure to call this function after FlatRedBallServices.Update, but before any custom game logic (such as ScreenManager.Activity).
member.param: The state containing the data for this frame.

member.summary: Sets the vibration of the game pad.
member.remarks: Note that on MonoGame 3.8.1 for Xbox360 and Xbox One controllers, this method will not vibrate the controller until a button is pressed.
member.param: The low-frequency motor. Set between 0.0f and 1.0f
The high-frequency motor. Set between 0.0f and 1.0f
member.returns: True if the vibration motors were successfully set; false if the controller was unable to process the request.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Input.IPressableInputExtensions
member.summary: Class including extension methods on the IPressableInput interface.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Input.IPressableInputExtensions.And(FlatRedBall.Input.IPressableInput,FlatRedBall.Input.IPressableInput)
member.summary: Returns an IPressableInput which requires both of the provided inputs to be true for its inputs to be true. In other words: AndPressableInput.WasJustPressed is equivalent to (input1.WasJustPressed && input2.WasJustPressed) and so on.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Input.IPressableInputExtensions.Or(FlatRedBall.Input.IPressableInput,FlatRedBall.Input.IPressableInput)
member.summary: Returns an IPressableInput which requires any of the provided inputs to be true for its inputs to be true. In other words: OrPressableInput.WasJustPressed is equivalent to (input1.WasJustPressed || input2.WasJustPressed) and so on.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Input.IPressableInputExtensions.AndNot(FlatRedBall.Input.IPressableInput,FlatRedBall.Input.IPressableInput)
member.summary:
Returns an IPressableInput which requires the first of the provided inputs to be true and the second of the provided inputs to be false for its inputs to be true. In other words: AndNotPressableInput.WasJustPressed is equivalent to (input1.WasJustPressed && !input2.WasJustPressed) and so on.
Does not support checking for repeat inputs.

member.param: The IPressableInput to use as a 1DInput
member.returns: The resulting I1DInput.

member.remarks: This is useful for games which want to read from multiple devices, such as letting all controllers control one character, or letting keyboard and gamepad control a character at the same time.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Instructions.DelegateInstruction

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Instructions.DelegateInstruction.Target
member.summary: The target for DelegateInstruction doesn't have any internal purpose - it's used purely to help games track what has generated instructions.
member.remarks: This used to be a null getter only, but now it stores data so that projects like Gum can assign owners of an instruction.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Instructions.Instruction
member.summary: Class that supports the execution of custom logic at a future time.
member.remarks: Instructions are either stored and executed through the InstructionManager or managed IInstructable instances.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Instructions.Instruction.mTimeToExecute
member.summary: The system time to execute the instruction at.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Instructions.Instruction.mCycleTime
member.summary: The amount of time to add to the instruction for cycled execution. Default of 0 instructs the executing logic to not cycle the Instruction.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Instructions.Instruction.TimeToExecute
member.summary: The game time to check for execution.
member.remarks: The TimeManager.CurrentTime property is used for comparisons.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Instructions.Instruction.CycleTime
member.summary: The amount of time between executions for an instruction that cycles. If this value is 0, the instruction does not cycle. CycleTime is only considered after an instructions first execution. This means that an instruction may be scheuduled to execute in 10 seconds, then after its first execution it will repeat every second thereafter.
member.example: Setting a CycleTime of 1 means that the instruction will execute ever 1 second after its first execution.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Instructions.InstructionManager.Instructions
member.summary: Holds instructions which will be executed by the InstructionManager in its Update method (called automatically by FlatRedBallServices). This list is sorted by time.
member.remarks: Instructions for managed PositionedObjects like Sprites and Text objects should be added to the object's internal InstructionList. This prevents instructions from referencing removed objects and helps with debugging. This list should only be used on un-managed objects or for instructions which do not associate with a particular object.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Instructions.InstructionManager.IsExecutingInstructions
member.summary: Whether the (automatically called) Update method executes instructions. Default true.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Instructions.InstructionSet
member.summary: Represents a set of KeyframeLists which can be applied to objects or used to perform scripted events.
member.remarks:
When used to perform scripted events, InstructionSets can be compared to texture animation. There are many levels of Lists in an InstructionSet. The following comparison to AnimationChainLists provides some clarity to the layers:
InstructionSet (List of KeyframeLists) : AnimationChainList (List of AnimationChains)
KeyframeList (List of Keyframes - aka InstructionLists) : AnimationChain (List of AnimationFrames)
InstructionList (Applied to an object to change any properties) : AnimationFrame (Applied to an object to change its appearance);

The file type to search for specified as an extension. The extension can either have a period or not. That is ".jpg" and "jpg" are both valid fileType arguments. An empty or null value for this parameter will return all files regardless of file type.

The file type to search for specified as an extension. The extension can either have a period or not. That is ".jpg" and "jpg" are both valid fileType arguments. An empty or null value for this parameter will return all files regardless of file type.
The depth to search through. If the depthToSearch is 0, only the argument directory will be searched.
member.returns: A list containing all of the files found which match the fileType.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.ManagedSpriteGroups.SpriteFrame.UpdateInternalSpriteNames
member.summary: Sets the contained DynamicSpriteFrame to help identify SpriteFrame membership and side.
member.remarks:
If the SpriteFrame's name is "spriteFrame1", each side will have its name be the SpriteFrame's name with a suffix indicating the side that the Sprite represents. That is, the center Sprite would be named "spriteFrame1_center", the top would be "spriteFrame1_top", and so on.
This method can be used in debugging to help identify whether DynamicSprites belong to a SpriteFrame, and if so, which side they represent. Otherwise, this method has no engine functionality.

member.summary: Creates a new SpriteGrid.
member.remarks: The mBlueprintToUse argument Sprite reference is kept internally and used as the blue print. In other words, the SpriteGrid does not create a new Sprite internally, but uses the arguemnt Sprite. When creating SpriteGrids in code, it is common to create a new Sprite only to serve as a SpriteGrid blue print, then remove it from the SpriteManager's memory. If the Sprite passed as the mBlueprintToUse is modified after the SpriteGrid is created, this will change the SpriteGrid bluerint
member.param: Reference to the camnera used to determine whether a point on the SpriteGrid is in the scren.
Whether the SpriteGrid should extend on the XY or XZ plane.
Reference to a Sprite representing the mBlueprint to be used for the grid.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.ManagedSpriteGroups.SpriteGrid.Destroy
member.summary: Destroys the SpriteGrid by removing all contained Sprites and clearing the TextureGrid.

remarks.para: This method will only remove all contained Sprites from the SpriteManager and clear out the TextureGrid. The SpriteGrid will still reference the the blueprint Sprite and have the same Bounds and GridSpacing.

If the Manage method is called after this method is called, the SpriteGrid will throw an out of bounds exception. To refill the SpriteGrid after this method has been called, it must first be populated.

member.summary: Clears all Sprites referenced by the SpriteGrid.
member.remarks:
This method will only remove all contained Sprites from the SpriteManager. This method does not clear out the TextureGrid.
If the Manage method is called after this method is called, the SpriteGrid will throw an out of bounds exception. To refill the SpriteGrid after this method has been called, it must first be populated.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.ManagedSpriteGroups.TextureGrid`1.ChangeGrid(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Shifts the position of all textures in the TextureGrid.
member.param: The distance along the x axis to shift the grid.
The distance along the y axis to shift the grid.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.ManagedSpriteGroups.TextureGrid`1.ReduceGrid(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: This "shrinks" the grid if its edges are the same as its baseTexture
member.remarks:
To use the least amount of memory, TextureGrids only store non-baseTexture strips. If the ends of a horizontal strip are the baseTexture, then the strip should be contracted inward. If an entire horizontal strip is the baseTexture, then it should be removed.
Usually, tests should begin from a specific location, as it is usually called after the grid is painted. This method will first check to see if the arguments are on the left or right side of a strip. Then a loop will move inward as long as it continues to encounter the base texture. Once it encounters a non-baseTexture, then it stops, and reduces the particular horizontal strip.
If an entire strip is cleared and it is either the top or bottom strip, then it will be removed, and the strip above or below (depending on position) will be tested as well. If the strip is in the center (not the top or bottom), then it will be reduced, but cannot be removed.
member.param: The y location in absolute coordinates to start the tests at.
The x location in absolute coordinates to start the tests at.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.ManagedSpriteGroups.TextureGrid`1.ReduceGridAtIndex(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: This "shrinks" the grid if its edges are the same as its baseTexture
member.remarks:
To use the least amount of memory, TextureGrids only store non-baseTexture strips. If the ends of a horizontal strip are the baseTexture, then the strip should be contracted inward. If an entire horizontal strip is the baseTexture, then it should be removed.
Usually, tests should begin from a specific location, as it is usually called after the grid is painted. This method will first check to see if the arguments are on the left or right side of a strip. Then a loop will move inward as long as it continues to encounter the base texture. Once it encounters a non-baseTexture, then it stops, and reduces the particular horizontal strip.
If an entire strip is cleared and it is either the top or bottom strip, then it will be removed, and the strip above or below (depending on position) will be tested as well. If the strip is in the center (not the top or bottom), then it will be reduced, but cannot be removed.
member.param: The y index start the tests at.
The x index to start the tests at.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.ManagedSpriteGroups.TextureGrid`1.TrimGrid
member.summary: Checks the boundaries of the grid and removes any references to textures that match the base Texture2D.
member.remarks: This method is called automatically by the ReplaceTexture method so that the structure stays as small as possible afterchanges have been made.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject
member.summary: Represents an object with position, rotation, ability to store instructions, and attachment abilities.
member.remarks:
The PositionedObject is a common object in FlatRedBall. It is the root class for a number of FlatRedBall classes including Sprites, Texts, SpriteFrames, PositionedModels, and all Shapes.
The PositionedObject class is also used as the base class for Glue entities.
PositionedObjects can be automatically managed by being added to the SpriteManager.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.Position
member.summary: The absolute world position of the instance.
member.remarks: This mirrors the X, Y, and Z properties. This value essentially becomes read-only if this object has a Parent.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RelativePosition
member.summary: The position of the object relative to its Parent in its Parent's coordinate space.
member.remarks: These values become the dominant controller of absolute Position if this instance has a Parent. These values have no impact if the instance does not have a Parent.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.Velocity
member.summary: The absolute world velocity of the instance measured in units per second.
member.remarks: This mirrors the XVelocity, YVelocity, and ZVelocity properties. This value is essentially invalid if this instance has a Parent.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RelativeVelocity
member.summary: The velocity of the object relative to its Parent in its Parent's cooridnate space.
member.remarks: This value modifies the RelativePosition field even if the object does not have a Parent.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.Acceleration
member.summary: The absolute world acceleration of the instance measured in units per second per second.
member.remarks:
This mirrors the XAcceleration, YAcceleration, and ZAcceleration properties. This value is essentially invalid if the instance has a Parent; however, it can still build up the Velocity value.
If an object with a parent has a non-zero Acceleration for a significant amount of time, then is detached, the Velocity will likely be non-zero and may be very large causing the object to move rapidly.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RelativeAcceleration
member.summary: The acceleration of the object relative to its Parent in its Parent's coordinate space.
member.remarks: This value modifies the RelativeVelocity field even if the object does not have a Parent.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RealVelocity
member.summary: The actual velocity of the object from the last frame to this frame. This value is only valid if the KeepTrackOfReal property has been true for over one frame.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RealAcceleration
member.summary: The actualy acceleration of the object from the last frame to this frame. This value is only valid if the KeepTrackOfReal property has been set to true for over two frames.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.LastPosition
member.summary: The last Position of the object - used to calculate the RealVelocity field. This is valid only if the KeepTrackOfReal property is true.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.LastVelocity
member.summary: The last Velocity of the object - this is used to calculate the RealAcceleration field. This is valid only if the KeepTrackOfReal property is true.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.mDrag
member.summary: The drag of the instance.

member.summary: The name of the instance.

member.summary: The lists that this instance belongs to. This is how two-way relationships are implemented.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.IgnoreParentPosition
member.summary: Controls whether this instance ignores parent positioning. This is false by default, which means Relative values are used to determine this instance's absolute positions when it has a parent. If this is set to true, then the positioning of this object behaves as if it was not attached. Rotation and other properties which may be affected by a Parent still apply.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.mLastDependencyUpdate
member.summary: The value that was last used when calling UpdateDependencies.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.ListsBelongingTo
member.summary: The List of lists that this belongs to. This member is how two-way relationships are established. If an object is added to a list using a "one-way" add, then that list will not be in the object's ListsBelongingTo.
member.remarks: PositionedObjects are typically added to managers, children, and Glue lists using two-way relationships, so this member provides information about where this object is referenced.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.Name
member.summary: The instance's name.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.Parent
member.summary: The PositionedObject that this instance is attached to.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.ParentRotationChangesPosition
member.summary: Whether the parent's rotation should change the object's position.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.ParentRotationChangesRotation
member.summary: Gets and sets whether the parent's rotation should change the object's rotation. The default is true, which means if this is attached to a parent, it will rotate along with the parent, and it can have additional rotation applied through its relative rotation values. If this value is false, then the relative values are applied directly to the absolute values, ignoring the parent's rotation.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RelativeX
member.summary: Gets and sets the X position relative to the instance's parent.
member.remarks: If the instance does not have a parent this property has no effect.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RelativeY
member.summary: Gets and sets the Y position relative to the instance's parent.
member.remarks: If the instance does not have a parent this property has no effect.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RelativeZ
member.summary: Gets and sets the Z position relative to the instance's parent.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RelativeRotationZ
member.summary: The z rotation of a PositionedObject relative to its parent in radians. Only applies if this instance is attached to a parent.
member.remarks:
This rotates the PositionedObject about the Z axis if it is attached to a parent. Rotation is represented in radians. Angles will always be greater than or equal to 0 and less than two times PI. Values outside of these bounds will be regulated by the set property.
RelativeRotationZ can be used to "spin" a PositionedObject, with a positive variable spinning counterclockwise.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RelativeRotationMatrix
member.summary: The rotation representing the orientation relative to the instance's Parent.
member.remarks: If the instance does not have a Parent then this property has no effect.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RelativeRotationXVelocity
member.summary: Gets and sets the rate of change of the RelativeRotationX property in units per second.

member.summary: Gets and sets the rate of change of the RelativeRotationY property in units per second.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RelativeRotationZVelocity
member.summary: Gets and sets the rate of change of the RelativeRotationZ property in units per second.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.LastDependencyUpdate
member.summary: The last time Update was called.
member.remarks: This value is set through the TimeManager's CurrentTime property.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RotationX
member.summary: The x rotation of a PositionedObject
member.remarks:
This rotates the PositionedObject about the X axis. Rotation is represented in radians. Angles will always be greater than or equal to 0 and less than two times PI. Values outside of these bounds will be regulated by the set property.
RotationX can be used to flip an image of a PositionedObject, but a PositionedObject should not be flipped during animation (if it is a Sprite). AnimationFrames can be flipped without setting a Sprite's Rotation values.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RotationY
member.summary: The y rotation of a PositionedObject
member.remarks:
This rotates the PositionedObject about the Y axis. Rotation is represented in radians. Angles will always be greater than or equal to 0 and less than two times PI. Values outside of these bounds will be regulated by the set property.
RotationY can be used to flip an image and set it upside down, but a PositionedObject should not be flipped during animation (if it is a Sprite). AnimationFrames can be flipped without setting a Sprite's Rotation values.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RotationZ
member.summary: The z rotation of a PositionedObject in radians.
member.remarks:
This rotates the PositionedObject about the Z axis. Rotation is represented in radians. Angles will always be greater than or equal to 0 and less than two times PI. Values outside of these bounds will be regulated by the set property.
RotationZ can be used to "spin" a PositionedObject, with a positive variable spinning counterclockwise.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RotationMatrix
member.summary: The matrix applied to the object resulting in its final orientation.
member.remarks: The RotationMatrix and RotationX, RotationY, RotationZ reflect eachother. Changing one will change the other.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.TransformationMatrix

member.remarks: Changing the transformation matrix will change rotation, position and scaling

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RelativeTransformationMatrix
member.summary: Gets or sets the overall transformation of this object, relative to its parent
member.remarks: Changing the transformation matrix will change rotation, position and scaling

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.RotationYVelocity
member.summary: The absolute Y rotation speed measured in radians per second
member.remarks: The RotationYVelocity variable is how fast a PositionedObject is rotating on the Y axis. It is measured in radians per second.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.Drag
member.summary: Linear approximation of drag. This reduces the Velocity of the instance according to its absolute Velocity.
member.remarks:
The following formula is applied to apply Drag:
Velocity -= Velocity * Drag * TimeManager.SecondDifference; Note that a very large Drag value may result in an object moving in the opposite direction.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.Instructions
member.summary: The list of Instructions that this instance owns. These instructions usually will execute on this instance; however, this is not a requirement.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.CreationSource
member.summary: Where the PositionedObject was created. This can be Glue, Tiled, or other tools. It is used when the game is in edit mode to determine if the PositionedObject can be edited.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.#ctor
member.summary: Creates a new PositionedObject instance.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.AreSubHierarchiesIdentical(FlatRedBall.PositionedObject,FlatRedBall.PositionedObject)
member.summary: Determines whether the tree structure created by attachments of two PositionedObjects are identical.
member.remarks: This method does not investigate the PositionedObjects any more than looking at their children. It traverses through the trees multiple times, and can be a very slow method if the PositionedObjects have large subtrees. The subtrees are small enough in most cases where there won't be a performance issue.
member.param: The first PositionedObject.
The second PositionedObject.
member.returns: Whether the tree structure created by attachments is the same.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.AttachTo(FlatRedBall.PositionedObject)
member.summary: Attaches this to the argument PositionedObject (sets this.Parent). This method does not change relative values, so "this" may "snap" to the new parent's position.
member.param: The new parent.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.AttachTo(FlatRedBall.PositionedObject,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Attaches this PositionedObject to the argument newParent.

remarks.para: A useful way to understand the affect of changeRelative is to consider that it is the opposite of whether absolute values change. That is, if the relative values do not change upon attachment, the absolute values will change.

For an example, consider a situation where a child has an absolute x value of 5 and a relative value of 0 and a parent has an absolute x value of 0. If the child is attached to the parent and relative is not changed (relative x remains at 0), then the child's x will be parent.x + child.relX, or 0 + 0 = 0. We see that the relative value didn't change, so the absolute did.

If, on the other hand, the relative was changed, the absolute position would be the same. Since the parent's absolute position was 0 and the absolute position of the child should remain at 5, then the relX value would change to 5 (assuming the parent isn't rotated).

member.param: The PositionedObject to attach to.
Whether relative values should change so that absolute values stay the same.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.ClearRelationships
member.summary: Detaches this PositionedObject from its parent and detaches all of the PositionedObject's Children.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.CopyFieldsTo(FlatRedBall.PositionedObject)
member.summary: Copies most internal fields of this instance to the argument PositionedObjects.
member.remarks:
The following fields are not copied:
* Name
* ListsBelongingTo
* Parent
* Children
* Instructions

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.CopyAbsoluteToRelative
member.summary: Copies the absolute position and rotation values to the relative values.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.CreateNewChildrenList
member.summary: Creates a new Children PositionedObjectList.
member.remarks: This method is only necessary if a PositionedObject is manually cloned by calling MemberwiseClone. This should not be called to detach children as the two-way relationship between PositionedObject and PositionedObjectList will keep the old Children PositionedObjectList in scope resulting in a memory leak.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.CreateNewInstructionsList
member.summary: Creates a new InstructionList.
member.remarks: This method is only necessary if a PositionedObject is manually cloned by calling MemberwiseClone. This should not be called to clear the Instructions property as it will create a new instance and get rid fo the old one resulting in unnecessary garbage collection.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.Detach
member.summary: Detaches the PositionedObject from its parent PositionedObject.
member.remarks: This method cleans up the two way relationship between parent and child.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.ExecuteInstructions(System.Double)
member.summary: Executes instructions according to the argument currentTime and cycles and reorders Instructions as necessary.
member.param: The current time to compare the instruction's TimeToExecute against.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.ForceUpdateDependencies
member.summary: Forces an update of the PositionedObject's absolute position and rotation values according to its attachment and relative values.
member.remarks:
The absolute positions and rotations of Sprites are updated in the Sprite.UpdateDependencies method which is called in the SpriteManager.UpdateDependencies. The SpriteManager.UpdateDependencies is called once per frame by default in the Sprite's regular activity. This method only needs to be called if changes are made after the UpdateDependencies method has been called for that particular frame or if updated positions are needed immediately after relative values or attachments have been changed.
This method will recur up the hierarchical PositionedObject struture stopping when it hits the top parent.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.PositionedObject.GetAllDescendantsOneWay(FlatRedBall.Math.AttachableList{FlatRedBall.PositionedObject})
member.summary: Fills the argument list with the instance's parent, grandparent, etc. recursively.
member.param: The list to fill.

member.name: T:FlatRedBall.Screens.Screen
member.summary: Base class for screens typically defined through Glue.

member.name: F:FlatRedBall.Screens.Screen.mTimeScreenWasCreated
member.summary: The time using FlatRedBall.CurrentTime (time since the app started running) which is used to determine the screen time.
member.remarks: This value starts at 0 when a Screen is first created. This can be modified to restart screen timer, but it can cause unexpected side effects for systems which depend on timing, so this should not be changed in normal gameplay.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Screens.Screen.RestartVariableValues
member.summary: Stores the names and values of variables which should be preserved on the next restart. These values are recorded prior to the screen being destroyed, then applied after the construction of the next screen. These values are used internally in the base screen class and should not be modified.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Screens.Screen.RestartVariables
member.summary: A collection of variables to reset. This can be variables on the Screen itself or variables on objects within the screen, like this.PlayerInstance.X. Note that any objects which belong to the screen must begin with the name "this".

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Screens.Screen.Instructions
member.summary: The list of instructions owned by this screen.
member.remarks: These instructions will be automatically executed based off of time. Execution of these instructions is automatically handled by the InstructionManager.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Screens.Screen.ShouldRemoveLayer
member.summary: [Deprecated] Whether the Screen's Layer should be removed when the Screen is destroyed. This will be removed in future versions of FlatRedBall.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Screens.Screen.AccumulatedPauseTime
member.summary: Returns how much time the Screen has spent paused

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Screens.Screen.PauseAdjustedCurrentTime
member.summary: Returns the number of seconds since the Screen was initialized, excluding paused time. This value begins at 0 when the Screen is first created and is reset when the screen restarts.
member.remarks: If a screen is never paused, then its PauseAdjustedCurrentTime value increases regularly. If a screen is never paused and it is the first screen in the game, then PauseAdjustedCurrentTime will equal TimeManager.CurrentTime.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Screens.Screen.ScreenDestroy
member.summary: Action raised when this screen is destroyed. This can be used to create flow objects or for top-level debugging/game editors.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Screens.Screen.IsActivityFinished
member.summary: Gets and sets whether the activity is finished for a particular screen. Setting this to true will notify the Screen that it should destroy itself and move on to the next screen.
member.remarks: If activity is finished, then the ScreenManager or parent screen (if the screen is a popup) knows to destroy the screen and loads the NextScreen class.

member.name: P:FlatRedBall.Screens.Screen.NextScreen
member.summary: The name of the Screen-inheriting to load next. This can be fully qualified "Namespace.Screens.ScreenName" or just the screen name. If just a screen name is specified then current screen's namespace will be prepended. to link to.
member.remarks: This property is read by the ScreenManager when IsActivityFinished is set to true. Therefore, this must always be set to some value before or in the same frame as when IsActivityFinished is set to true.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Screens.Screen.Destroy
member.summary: Performs the unloading of content and destroys all contained objects. Typically this method should not be called directly, but instead the IsActivityFinished property is set to true, which internally calls Destroy.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Screens.Screen.PauseThisScreen
member.summary: Pauses all Instructable objects, disables collision, and sets IsPaused to true.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Screens.Screen.UnpauseThisScreen
member.summary: Executes all Unpause instructions, enables collision, and sets the IsPaused property to false.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Screens.Screen.PauseAdjustedSecondsSince(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the number of seconds since the argument time for the current screen, considering pausing.
member.example: PauseAdjustedSecondsSince can be used to determine if some timed event has expired. For example: bool isCooldownFinished = PauseAdjustedSecondsSince(lastAbilityUse) >= CooldownTime;
member.param: The time from which to check how much time has passed.
member.returns: How much time has passed since the parameter value.

member.name: M:FlatRedBall.Screens.Screen.RestartScreen(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Destroys and re-creates this screen.
member.remarks: This can be used to begin a level from the beginning or to reload a screen for debugging.
member.param: Whether the screen's content should be reloaded. If true, then any content that belongs to this Screen's content manager will be reloaded. Global content will not be reloaded.

Whether to apply restart variables. If true, then any restart variables will be applied, which is useful when iterating on a game. This should be false if restarting due to gameplay events such as a player dying.

The parent object, allowing variables like this.Object.Subobject, where Object is the parent.

The container of the object. Should be null for objects contained in the screen.

If not, an informative exception is thrown indicating what is left over. Normally this is not called in custom code since it is automatically called by the ScreenManager when a Screen is transitioning.
